name: Rakan Al-Oraifi
detail: Among the many accolades he has received, Al-Oraifi was hailed Best Saudi Chef at the 2018 Saudi Excellence in Tourism Awards and has worked in several international restaurants over the years. He has also taken part in several international cooking competitions, including Top Chef Middle East season two. In his work, Al-Oraifi especially likes to explore traditional Saudi cuisine, but infused with modern elements. His earliest memory of cooking goes back to making dolma with his mother. It is a dish I have been preparing since I was six. It was challenging to prepare it as a young kid, but I would always prepare it with my mom over the years and eventually learned to prepare it on my own, said Al-Oraifi in an interview with Arab News.

recipes.name: MANSAF
cooking_method: In a large pot, bring about 6 cups of water to a boil. Add the lamb shoulder, chopped onion, minced garlic, cumin, salt, and black pepper. Reduce the heat to medium-low and let the lamb simmer for about 2 hours, until it's tender and the meat is falling off the bone. Skim off any foam that rises to the surface.
Remove the lamb from the pot and place it on a platter. Reserve the cooking liquid (broth) for later.

In a separate bowl, whisk together the yogurt with 1/2 cup of the reserved lamb broth. Set aside.Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 2 hours or up to overnight.In a separate bowl, whisk together the yogurt with 1/2 cup of the reserved lamb broth. Set aside.

Rinse the rice in cold water, then drain and place it in a large pot with 4 cups of the reserved lamb broth. Add salt to taste. Bring the rice to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and let it simmer, covered, for about 20 minutes, until the rice is cooked and the liquid is absorbed.
In a small pan, melt the ghee or clarified butter over medium heat. Add the toasted pine nuts and stir until they're coated with the ghee.

To assemble the Mansaf, place the cooked rice on a large serving platter. Arrange the lamb shoulder on top of the rice. Pour the yogurt sauce over the lamb and rice. Sprinkle the pine nuts over the top.
Serve the Mansaf hot, with additional yogurt sauce and rice on the side.

recipes.name: FALAFEL
cooking_method: Drain the soaked chickpeas and place them in a food processor with the chopped onion, minced garlic, chopped parsley, chopped cilantro, ground cumin, ground coriander, baking soda, salt, and black pepper. Pulse the mixture until it's well combined, but still slightly coarse in texture.
Transfer the falafel mixture to a bowl and cover it with plastic wrap. Refrigerate the mixture for at least 1 hour (or up to overnight) to allow it to firm up and the flavors to meld together.
Using your hands or a small scoop, shape the falafel mixture into small balls or patties, about 1-2 inches in diameter.
In a large, deep skillet or a pot, heat about 1 inch of vegetable oil over medium-high heat until it's hot but not smoking.

Carefully add the falafel balls or patties to the hot oil, working in batches if necessary to avoid overcrowding the pan. Fry the falafel for about 2-3 minutes per side, until they're golden brown and crispy. Use a slotted spoon to transfer the fried falafel to a paper towel-lined plate to drain any excess oil.
Serve the falafel hot, with pita bread, tahini sauce, hummus, chopped tomatoes, cucumbers, and pickles, as desired.

Falafel can also be baked in the oven for a healthier, oil-free version. Simply preheat the oven to 375°F (190°C), place the falafel on a lined baking sheet, and bake for about 20-25 minutes, flipping halfway through, until they're golden brown and crispy.

recipes.name: HUMMUS
ingredients: 2 cups cooked chickpeas (or 1 can chickpeas, drained and rinsed)
Water or reserved chickpea cooking liquid, as needed
cooking_method: In a food processor or blender, combine the cooked chickpeas, tahini, lemon juice, minced garlic, olive oil, ground cumin, salt, and black pepper. Pulse the mixture until it's smooth and creamy.
If the hummus is too thick, add water or reserved chickpea cooking liquid, a tablespoon at a time, until you reach your desired consistency.
Taste the hummus and adjust the seasoning as needed, adding more salt, pepper, or lemon juice to taste.
Transfer the hummus to a serving bowl and drizzle with a little extra olive oil. Garnish with fresh parsley, paprika, or toasted pine nuts, if desired.
Serve the hummus with pita bread, fresh vegetables, or crackers for dipping.

To make the hummus extra smooth, you can remove the skins from the cooked chickpeas before processing them. Simply rub the chickpeas between your fingers to loosen the skins, then rinse them in a bowl of water to separate the skins, which will float to the top. Skim off the skins and discard them, then proceed with the recipe.
